results:
Based on the search results, I can provide you with comprehensive information about Pan Tadeusz's UNESCO Memory of the World recognition, international academic studies, and translations:

## UNESCO Memory of the World Recognition

In 2014 the manuscript of "Pan Tadeusz" was included in the UNESCO Memory of the World list as one of the most treasured relics of Polish national culture. This recognition was also confirmed by another source, which states that In 2014 Pan Tadeusz was incorporated into Poland's list in the UNESCO Memory of the World Programme.

## International Recognition and Significance

Pan Tadeusz, Poland's national epic, is compulsory reading in Polish schools and has been translated into 33 languages. The work has achieved remarkable international reach and academic interest, as evidenced by its extensive translation history and ongoing scholarly attention.

## Translations

Pan Tadeusz has been translated into numerous languages over more than a century:

### Historical Timeline of Translations:
- The earliest translation of Pan Tadeusz was into Belarusian by the Belarusian writer and dramatist Vintsent Dunin-Martsinkyevich, in Vilnius in 1859.
- Other translations of "Pan Tadeusz" include Russian (1882), Esperanto (1918), French (1934), German (1955), Czech (1969), Lithuanian (1974), and Kashubian—a West Slavic minority language—in Poland (2010).

### English Translations:
English translations of "Pan Tadeusz" in the collections of the Library of Congress include editions from 1917, 1930, and 1962, with about half a dozen more through 2009. The translation work continues to the present day, with the latest English translation was published this year.

## Academic Studies and International Impact

The academic significance of Pan Tadeusz is highlighted by the fact that In the assessment process much value is attributed to translations. If literary works have been translated into many languages, this is a clear indication of their global impact and significance.

## Preservation and Display

Pan Tadeusz is required reading in Polish schools, and its original manuscript is considered to be the most important holding of the Ossolineum. The original manuscript is on display in the Pan Tadeusz Museum in Wrocław, which opened in 2016.

The work's international recognition extends beyond academic circles, as Google's Doodle for Poland, Lithuania, Belarus, Iceland, Ireland and UK on 28 June 2019 commemorated the poem.

This extensive international recognition, translation history, and academic significance all contributed to Pan Tadeusz's inclusion in the UNESCO Memory of the World Programme, cementing its status as a work of global cultural importance.
